Key Arguments: The government should not be exempt from the Bill as it can also spread misinformation.
Australians should have the right to free speech and independent thinking, diverging from government narratives.
The Bill should focus on misinformation and disinformation from foreign powers, not private citizens.
The Bill could lead to censorship by imposing fines on digital providers.
Encouraging open debate and discussion is a better approach to combating misinformation.
The Bill undermines Australians' ability to critically think and make their own decisions.
The Bill is similar to legislation in the USA, which has been criticized as an attack on free speech.
Notable Quotes: We should have a fundamental right in Australia to free speech and independent thinking that diverges from government propaganda and positions.
This Bill does not respect Australians and their ability to make up their own minds on issues and instead seeks to impose a nanny state of control over citizens and residents.

A better way to combat misinformation and disinformation is by having full and frank discussions of all sides of an issue, all opinions and all research and this Bill seems aimed at preventing that discourse.
